Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Issue with 7z.Libs support for .Netframework Integration" (#10276) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

Other

### Describe the bug

We are currently facing issue with integrating 7z.libs in to our .NET Framework application. Although the site mentioned that 7z.libs is compatible with .NET framework, we are encountering the issues, the files are empty in lib folder and 7z.libs is not getting added to our project reference, Could you please assist us in resolving this or provide a guidance on how to properly integrated 7z.libs with our project, we look forward to your response,

[7z.Libs 24.08.0](https://www.nuget.org/packages/7z.Libs/24.8.0)
![Screenshot 2024-11-20 202716](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/86b9a576-d90f-49df-a620-cb5bf191e15a)


### Repro Steps

1. Create a .NET Framework apllication
2. right click on project reference and try to add 7Z.libs or run NuGet\Install-Package 7z.Libs -Version 24.8.0

### Expected Behavior

The lib folder should contains the necessary files and the reference should get added in our project.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Copy list of scopes before removing them from the EF context" (#10275) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
A collection modified exception is thrown since internally the DbContext modifies the collection we are enumerating.

Over 99% of requests are failing on this endpoint and this has been happening since 2024-08-22.
 
Fix https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/10273.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Api query does not return all results, compared to web search" (#10274) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

When I search for my Nuget packages via nuget.org, I currently get 40 packages as a result set. If I search via the api, with the same term, I always get one result less.

- nuget.org: [www.nuget.org/packages?q=netevolve](https://www.nuget.org/packages?q=netevolve)
- api: [api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=netevolve](https://api-v2v3search-0.nuget.org/query?q=netevolve)

It is always the same package (https://www.nuget.org/packages/NetEvolve.Extensions.XUnit.V3), which is missing and I have not been able to identify the cause. I have also tried additional parameters such as for a pre-release, without success.

### Repro Steps

See enclosed links

### Expected Behavior

The same number of Nuget packages is listed for me.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Unable to edit API key" (#10273) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

When tried to edit API key in NuGet.org, It throws errors "An error occurred while editing an API key. Please try again."  
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/592a2960-18be-4025-a937-4b4542740941)


### Repro Steps

Steps to reproduce the issue:
1. Login to NuGet.org
2. Go to profile
3. Click on API keys
4. try to edit the API keys which is already created

### Expected Behavior

Should be able to edit the API key.

### Screenshots

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b71c4180-abe0-4cb3-9235-5fdbcf73b175)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "I'd like NuGet to give me a cue for different available updates." (#13948) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

If a newer package version targets the next version of .NET runtime, I cannot update the package without switching the runtime. This is fundamentally different from the case "There is a new version for **the same** .NET runtime you project targets". 

_I want to see this difference in the output of NuGet be it CLI or UI in VS._

Also, I'd like to have a dry run option for installing packages to see whether I'd be able to install a new version of the package without any issue like version conflict or version downgrade without actually installing the package. 
Seeing problematic packages in UI would be a nice addition to the DX.

### Additional Context and Details

If a newer package version targets the next version of .NET runtime, I cannot update the package without switching the runtime. This is fundamentally different from the case "There is a new version for **the same** .NET runtime you project targets". 

_I want to see this difference in the output of NuGet be it CLI or UI in VS._

Also, I'd like to have a dry run for adding package that is to see whether I'd be able to install a new version of the package without any issue like version conflict or version downgrade without actually installing the package. Seeing problematic packages in UI would also be a nice addition to the DX.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Include #13888 in known issues for 6.12" (#13890) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Update docs following change in default to NuGetAuditMode" (#13946) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Revert changes to NuGetAuditMode defaults" (#13945) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

In .NET 9 preview 6, and VS 17.12 preview 1, we changed NuGetAuditMode to `all`, so it will report both transitive and direct packages with known vulnerabilities.

### Desired Behavior

Restore .NET 8 SDK & VS 17.11's default to only report known vulnerabilities in directly referenced packages.

### Additional Context

We had documented mitigations like `WarningsNotAsErrors`, `SdkAnalysisLevel`, and `NuGetAuditSuppress` in several places. We tried to raise awareness in:

* VS Whats New window
* VS release notes
* .NET 9 release notes
* NuGet release notes
* NuGetAudit 2.0 blog post

Unfortunately, a sufficiently large number of customers didn't find/read any of these and were unable to resolve the problem without either reporting it as a bug or rolling back to the previous version. Therefore, management has decided that business continuity is more important than warning customers that their project is using packages with known vulnerabilities, and we're reverting this change.

Most of the concern is around "false positives" (System.* packages whose contents are not actually used because the framework's targeting pack provides assemblies with a higher version).  The consequence is that packages that pose a real security threat will no longer be warned about by default.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scream Test Impacting Alpine Linux Customers on 08/20/2024" (#73) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
On **August 20, 2024**, NuGet.org will conduct a **scream test** that may affect **Alpine Linux** customers. The test is scheduled to begin at **EDT 01:00 PM** and is expected to last between **24 to 72 hours**. We will adjust the test duration based on customer feedback.

During the scream test, **Alpine Linux** customers may encounter **DNS failures** from the [V3 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) due to this [issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9736). To mitigate, we recommend that Alpine Linux customers migrate to **Alpine Linux 3.18.0** or a newer version. These newer versions support **TCP fallback** in the DNS resolver.

To ensure uninterrupted service during the test, please use the [V2 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) instead.

If you have any **feedback**, **concerns**, or **questions**, feel free to reach out to us at support@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue: [NuGet/Home#12985](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/12985).
